newsitem.title: USA: Languorous dlr little changed as US trading thins.
newsitem.headline: Languorous dlr little changed as US trading thins.

text.p: A languorous dollar stood flat to lower at the U.S. midday as foreign exchange desks thinned ahead of the long Memorial Day weekend.
The Australian dollar and British pound -- big movers and shakers overnight -- had also settled down and dealers were expecting little-to-no action for the remainder of the session.
"The market is really very quiet," said Mark Gargano, managing director of currency derivatives at First Union National Bank. "Ranges are extremely tight today."
The dollar dipped down to session lows against the mark and fell to 115.25 yen in mid-morning trade, but began a slothful trip back up to the top of its tight range near midday.
"The dollar is well supported against the yen at 115.25/35 and dollar/mark is well supported at the 1.6880 level," said Bob Steiner, vice president on the foreign exchange desk at Mellon Bank.
"You may see some drifting up but not too much more than that at this point," he added.
At midday, the dollar was changing hands at 1.6905/15 marks, down from 1.6924/27 at the open. It was fetching 115.59/69 yen, just below its opening rate of 115.68/73.
Shortly after midday. the dollar pushed up above its opening levels against both the mark and yen.
The outlook for dollar/yen, dealers said, was dependent on the rate's ability to move above key resistance at 116.50 -- where offers are rumored to be lurking.
"We've seen a correction from the oversold condition but we need to get above 116.50 and 117 to make me believe we're going back to 120," said Gargano.

Traders pegged good support in the Australian dollar, which tumbled overnight after Australia's central bank cut official interest rates by 50 basis points, at $0.7630/40 and said a return to the $0.7750 area was in the cards for next week.
Sterling/mark, which fell sharply on Thursday, gained ground in U.S. trading, moving above the 2.76 threshold.
"Sterling/mark came from 2.78 down to 2.74 so a retracement back to 2.7650 is just about normal," said Mellon's Steiner, cautioning that another downward turn may be forthcoming.

Elsewhere at midday, the dollar had weakened to 1.4050/60 Swiss francs from 1.4070/80. Sterling was firmer at $1.6320/30 versus $1.6305/15. The dollar was stronger at Canadian $1.3735/40 against C$1.3729/34.
